subject: Storm Dudley
title: Storm Dudley: East Midlands told to expect disruption
article: A warning has been issued for strong winds that could cause disruption in the East Midlands and other parts of the country. Storm Dudley has prompted the Met Office to put out a yellow weather warning from Wednesday afternoon with 70mph (112 km/h) gusts expected. The National Trust said the Longshaw Estate in Derbyshire would close early due to the forecast. The yellow warning is in place until 06:00 GMT on Thursday. The Met Office warned the high winds could affect travel on roads and railways, damage trees and buildings, and cause power cuts. It added a second storm - Storm Eunice - is also expected later this week with a more severe amber warning for the region. BBC East Midlands weather presenter Sara Blizzard said Eunice had been classed as one of the UK's worst storms since January 2007. National Highways said vulnerable motorists were at risk of being "blown over" between 06:00 and 18:00 GMT on Friday. It said the M1 between junctions 22 and 23 in Leicestershire was a route of concern. Drivers of high-sided vehicles, caravans and motorbikes were advised to plan ahead and check their route before setting off. Follow BBC East Midlands on Facebook , on Twitter , or on Instagram . Send your story ideas to eastmidsnews@bbc.co.uk .
